Celiac disease is a digestive disease that can affect children and adults alike. Also known as celiac sprue, this disease is the most common genetic disease in Europe and is considered significantly underdiagnosed in the U.S. Learn more about the disease by taking this quiz.

When a person with celiac disease eats any of these grains, a protein called gluten found in them causes a reaction in his or her immune system. The immune system damages the tiny, fingerlike projections, called villi, that line the small intestine.

"Celiac is likely caused by both genetic factors (meaning it runs in families) and a trigger, which is gluten. The disease can develop in children and in adults, although it's unclear who will develop it when.

All of the diseases listed are autoimmune diseases, as is celiac disease. Other autoimmune diseases that may occur along with celiac disease include dermatitis herpetiformis, collagen vascular disease, and Sjogren\'s syndrome.

Symptoms of celiac disease include weight loss, diarrhea, excessive gas, behavior changes, delayed growth and failure to thrive (in child), seizures and infertility. Symptoms differ from person to person; some have only abdominal symptoms, others have no symptoms.

A person with celiac disease has higher than normal levels of certain antibodies. These antibodies can be measured with a blood test. If symptoms and the blood test suggest celiac disease, the doctor may then order a biopsy of the small intestine.

A person with celiac disease must avoid any foods that contain gluten. For most people, a gluten-free diet will stop symptoms, heal intestinal damage, and prevent further damage. The healing process can take from 6 months (children) to 2 years (adults).

These foods do not contain wheat gluten and so are safe to eat. In addition, flours made from these foods and corn grains are available for baking and cooking. Commercial food products may contain gluten in the form of additives, preservatives and stabilizers.

Lymphoma can develop in the small intestine of a person with celiac disease.
Because it may be difficult for a person with celiac disease to absorb enough calcium, osteoporosis may develop.
As for other nutrients, a woman who is pregnant may be at risk for miscarriage.
Seizures may be caused by poor absorption of folate.
